description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Drug Daily-- Current study results on Drugs and Therapies- Benzodiazepine Anticonvulsants have been published. Financial supporters for this research include National Council of Science and Technology, University of Guanajuato. The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Drug
Daily \-- Current study results on Drugs and Therapies - Benzodiazepine
Anticonvulsants have been published. According to news reporting from
Guanajuato, Mexico, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Under certain
conditions many pharmaceuticals can accumulate in organic phases due to their
low polarity. It is possible that with such drugs in the presence of other
substances, like surfactants, an accumulation phenomenon may occur."

Financial supporters for this research include National Council of Science and
Technology (CONACYT), University of Guanajuato.

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University
of Guanajuato, "In this work, a study has been performed in order to determine
the influence of surfactants, like soy lecithin, on the behavior of diazepam
and chlorpheniramine distribution between an organic and an aqueous phase.
First, the extraction of CPM and DZP without soy lecithin was evaluated. As
expected, the molecular form (non-charged) were the best extracted. The
extraction of CPM and DZP were close to 100% at pH 8.7 and pH 5, respectively.
On the other hand, the results show that the presence of a surfactant
increases the drug accumulation into the organic phase towards lower values of
pH, where the predominated forms of drugs are the protonated for
chlorpheniramine (CPMH+) and neutral for diazepam (DZP), this being more
important in the chlorpheniramine case which is extracted as CPMH+.SL-. A
model for extraction of both drugs was developed and tested: in absence of soy
lecithin partition coefficients of 181.7 and 19.1 were obtained for
chlorpheniramine and diazepam, respectively. In presence of soy lecithin, the
model considers the presence of CPME+ and (CPMH2) (2+) in the aqueous phase,
meanwhile in the organic phase the model takes into account as extracted
species CPMH+.SL- and CPM."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The extraction
constants values obtained were K-ext(,CPMH)+ = 0. 20 L.mol(-1) and
K-ext(,(CPMH2))2+ = 1.89*10(-6)."

For more information on this research see: Distribution Modeling of Diazepam
and Chlorpheniramine Between Aqueous and Non-polar Phases In the Presence of
Soy Lecithin. _Journal of Molecular Liquids_ , 2020;303():. _Journal of
Molecular Liquids_ can be contacted at: Elsevier, Radarweg 29, 1043 Nx
Amsterdam, Netherlands. (Elsevier \-
[www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com); Journal of Molecular Liquids \-
<http://www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-molecular-liquids/>)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting M. Avila-Rodriguez, University of Guanajuato, Dept. of Chemistry,
Cerro Venada S-N, Guanajuato 36040, Guanajuato, Mexico. Additional authors for
this research include T.A. Razo-Lazcano, P. Gonzalez-Munoz, M. Stambouli, D.
Pareau and J.A. Reyes-Aguilera.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2020.112653>. This DOI is a link to an
online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be
your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Reports on Benzodiazepine Anticonvulsants Findings from University of Guanajuato Provide New Insights (Distribution Modeling of Diazepam and Chlorpheniramine Between Aqueous and Non-polar Phases In the Presence of Soy Lecithin): Drugs and Therapies - Benzodiazepine Anticonvulsants
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Drug Daily -- Current study results on Drugs and Therapies - Benzodiazepine Anticonvulsants have been published. According to news reporting from Guanajuato, Mexico, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “Under certain conditions many pharmaceuticals can accumulate in organic phases due to their low polarity. It is possible that with such drugs in the presence of other substances, like surfactants, an accumulation phenomenon may occur.”

Financial supporters for this research include National Council of Science and Technology (CONACYT), University of Guanajuato.

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University of Guanajuato, “In this work, a study has been performed in order to determine the influence of surfactants, like soy lecithin, on the behavior of diazepam and chlorpheniramine distribution between an organic and an aqueous phase. First, the extraction of CPM and DZP without soy lecithin was evaluated. As expected, the molecular form (non-charged) were the best extracted. The extraction of CPM and DZP were close to 100% at pH 8.7 and pH 5, respectively. On the other hand, the results show that the presence of a surfactant increases the drug accumulation into the organic phase towards lower values of pH, where the predominated forms of drugs are the protonated for chlorpheniramine (CPMH+) and neutral for diazepam (DZP), this being more important in the chlorpheniramine case which is extracted as CPMH+.SL-. A model for extraction of both drugs was developed and tested: in absence of soy lecithin partition coefficients of 181.7 and 19.1 were obtained for chlorpheniramine and diazepam, respectively. In presence of soy lecithin, the model considers the presence of CPME+ and (CPMH2) (2+) in the aqueous phase, meanwhile in the organic phase the model takes into account as extracted species CPMH+.SL- and CPM.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “The extraction constants values obtained were K-ext(,CPMH)+ = 0. 20 L.mol(-1) and K-ext(,(CPMH2))2+ = 1.89*10(-6).”

For more information on this research see: Distribution Modeling of Diazepam and Chlorpheniramine Between Aqueous and Non-polar Phases In the Presence of Soy Lecithin. Journal of Molecular Liquids, 2020;303():. Journal of Molecular Liquids can be contacted at: Elsevier, Radarweg 29, 1043 Nx Amsterdam, Netherlands. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Journal of Molecular Liquids - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-molecular-liquids/)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting M. Avila-Rodriguez, University of Guanajuato, Dept. of Chemistry, Cerro Venada S-N, Guanajuato 36040, Guanajuato, Mexico. Additional authors for this research include T.A. Razo-Lazcano, P. Gonzalez-Munoz, M. Stambouli, D. Pareau and J.A. Reyes-Aguilera.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2020.112653. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
